Posts.Content: kay wrote: In 1995 my mom was diagnosed with bc and had a mastectomy and chemo. She has been in remission since then until 2 weeks ago. She was having pain that she thought was her sciatic nerve and went to ortho and had MRI. He then ordered petscan and she lit up in several areas. He then sent her to her onc who did bloodwork and a biopsy on her tailbone. He then met with her and told her that it was stage IV Metasis. It has spread to her lymphnodes, some small spots on her lungs, several bones in her spine, ribs, and femur. The most pain she experiences is in her femur and she has trouble getting up from a sitting position. She is going in Sat for another MRI of her legs to see if there is significant damge to the bones where she is having so much pain. Two weeks ago, I thought breat cancer was limited to the breast, so needless to say, I feel like we are in a whirlwind. I guess my question is, where do we start? I know that her onc will give us a treatment plan after the mri results and also after s test called"Fish test" But what questions should we be asking the onc? The terminology is overwhelming! I am trying to get familiar with it so I can help my mom ask the onc the right questions. Any suggestions from women who have been here would be greatly appreciated. Thankyou Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Help!New diagnosis for my mom and we don't know where to begin! kay mrs_X_Sunneedazee

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 11:25AM kay wrote: Thankyou all for your comments.  I feel like this comment board is more informational than any other source I have found. CTG, I can't thank you enough for listing out all of the things we should ask. I know that living past this disease is doable (is that a word?),and with all of your advice, I know we can start heading in that direction! Thankyou again Kay

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2008 06:05AM Kay-kay wrote: Compression garments: A German Company named Juzo (customized my sleeves and individual-fingered gloves)  I was/am satisfied with the results from using the products.  A company titled "The ReidSleeve People" customized my arm "boot" for night compression.  I call it a "boot" as it resembles a snow boot.  I chose hot pink!  Redirecting Lymph fluid to reduce swelling was the first thing I learned from the Lymphedema specialist.  She explained how we have three areas (six sections) of lymph nodes--the right & left armpits, the right & left neck and the right & left groin).  The Lymphedema therapist was great in training to recirculate the lymph fluid from my left side to other areas.  It was "tricky" as there are some obstacles caused by angled-openings and such...
Posts.Title: Compression garment questions Sher Kay-kay

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 05:40PM Kay-kay wrote: I am so tired of substandard health care resulting from ignorance!  Also having to perform my own research on everything is extensive. Why is BC, its s/e and treatments so subjective?  I had chemo on Monday (two days ago), and my chart was still on the doctor's desk today.  Therefore, when I arrived today (Wednesday) for a Neulasta shot I was told that I wasn't on the schedule.  There were five people looking for my chart, and it was on the desk of my Onc who is out until Friday.  On another note, I can't imagine having LE in both arms, as it's difficult enough being in my left.  I am excited to know that I could prevent it in my right by using wrist cuffs.  I never knew it could happen in both arms.  Eye-opener my me.
Posts.Title: Chipping Away at Lack of LE Education in the Medical Community LindaLou53 Kay-kay

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 07:38PM Kay-kay wrote: LindaLou, Much respect for the insight and adequate phrasing.  Now I feel like a moving target.  Do we have any control of our bodies?

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 12:13AM - edited Nov 15, 2008 12:31PM by Kay-kay Binney, I really appreciate your response.  Thanks for taking the time to reply and making me feel welcomed. Angled-openings: (my description) It is similar to a flap that only opens 45 degrees or so.  Therefore, the fluid has to enter a specific way or it will build up.   Much Appreciation!
Posts.Title: Compression garment questions Sher Kay-kay

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 11:51PM - edited Aug 1, 2012 11:54PM by Kay-in-NH Belinda,  Your diagnosis is similar to mine (IDC Stage 1B-C, 1.2 CM, Grade 2 Oncotype 19, ER+, PR+, HER-.  I had a clean wide margin surgery, and 0 of 6 lymph nodes (all clear), so the Med Onc said I was OK to skip chemo.  Did you?   I'm starting 6 1/2 weeks of RAD's on August 13th.  I don't think it will be bad, just a daily nuisance.  - Kay
